issues.description: The problem statement contains a conflicting specification for the Farm.animals collection: the UML diagram declares animals as List<Animal> while the textual Part 3 explicitly requires using a Set implemented with a HashSet. This contradiction leaves students unsure which collection type to implement (List vs Set) and whether duplicate animals must be prevented.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the contradiction in the problem statement. Prefer one explicit design and make both UML and textual instructions match. If the intent is to enforce uniqueness, update the UML and any UML text to show Set<Animal> (or HashSet) instead of List<Animal>. If a List is intended, change the textual Part 3 requirement to mention List/ArrayList and remove the HashSet mention.

issues.description: The solution implementation uses a List (ArrayList) for the Farm.animals attribute, while the textual Part 3 of the problem statement requires a Set backed by a HashSet. This mismatch between the solution and the problem's textual requirement (preventing duplicates) can confuse students who compare their implementations to the solution or rely on the solution as a reference implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the stated requirement in the problem text. Replace the List<Animal>/ArrayList usage with Set<Animal> and initialize it with new HashSet<>() in the Farm constructor; update getter/setter signatures if necessary and ensure addAnimal behaves appropriately. Alternatively, if the ArrayList usage was intentional, update the problem text to accept a List-based implementation and remove the HashSet requirement so all artifacts align.

issues.description: The problem statement contains conflicting representations for the Farm container type: the UML shows animals: List<Animal> while the textual task (Part 3) explicitly requires a Set implemented as a HashSet. The provided solution uses a List (ArrayList) for the Farm.animals field and constructor. This mismatch (List vs Set/HashSet) describes the same conceptual entity — the collection holding unique animals on the farm — with different identifiers/types across artifacts and will confuse students about which collection type they are required to implement (and whether uniqueness must be enforced).
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the collection type across all artifacts. Preferred fix (follow textual requirement): update the UML and any template comments to animals: Set<Animal>, and change the solution Farm.java to declare 'private Set<Animal> animals;' with 'this.animals = new HashSet<>();' (add the appropriate imports). If instead List was intended, update the problem text (Part 3) to say List/ArrayList and remove the HashSet/Set requirement so all artifacts consistently refer to the same collection concept.
